abstract.text: The
class allows your application to connect two iOS devices into a voice chat.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Before you can use voice chat, your application must configure an audio session that allows for both play and recording (
). For more information on audio sessions, see
The voice chat service uses a
implemented by your application to find and connect to other participants. Each participant in the chat is identified by a unique

string. The client provides a participant identifier for the local user and translates other participant identifiers into connections to other users.  The format and mechanism used to translate participant identifiers into network connections is defined by the client.
Your application can configure the voice chat service to control the volume level of both local and remote participants and to detect when someone is speaking.
To use the voice chat service, your application retrieves the default service and attaches a client to it, then either connects to another participant or waits for them to start a connection.

abstract.text: Allows recording (input) and playback (output) of audio, such as for a VOIP (voice over IP) app.
Enable players to interact with friends, compare leaderboard ranks, earn achievements, and participate in multiplayer games.
An
object provides a standard user interface to display achievement progress for the local player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
The
class is used to respond to events related to challenges sent or received by the local player.
The object representing the currently signed-in iCloud user.
Your game uses the
class to present a screen that allows the local player to send friend requests to other players.
The dashboard that allows players to access their Game Center data in your game.
A game session you can use to save game data, invite other players, and create turn-based and real-time game apps.
A user interface you can use to invite other users into a tvOS game session.

class provides a standard user interface that displays leaderboard scores to the player. If the
class is available, you should use it instead.
Provides a standard user interface to allow one iOS device to discover and connect to another.
An object containing information for a score that was earned by the player.
A
object provides the ability to discover and connect to nearby iOS devices using Bluetooth or Wi-fi.
The
class is used to respond to important messages related to turn-based matches. To use it, call the

property. All methods are called on the main thread.
The delegate for the event handler.

The
protocol is implemented by an object to receive notifications events for turn-based matches. All methods are called on the main thread.
A voice channel that allows players to speak with each other in a multiplayer game.
The
class allows your application to connect two iOS devices into a voice chat.
Accepts a request from a remote user to establish a voice chat.
An object that the voice chat service uses to communicate with remote participants.
Retrieves the singleton chat service.
Rejects a request to establish a voice chat.
The volume, in decibels (db), being received by the microphone.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the microphone’s sound level is being monitored.
A Boolean value that determines whether the user’s microphone is muted.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the voice level of remote participants is monitored.
Returns whether voice chat is allowed to be used on the device.
The volume, in decibels (db), being received from all other participants.
Called by the client to deliver new data received from a remote participant.
Called by the client to deliver voice data received from a remote participant..
A float that scales the volume of all remote participants.
Sends a request to another participant to join the voice chat.
Ends a previously established voice chat.
Error codes for the voice chat service error domain.
The
error domain.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
